title: C96-1062

sentences.text: A domain independent model is proposed for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English .
This model is meant to account for productive rules of interpretation which are inferred from the morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of the nominal constituents .
In particular , we make extensive use of Pustejovsky 's principles concerning the predicative information associated with nominals .
We argue that it is necessary to draw a line between generalizable semantic principles and domain-specific semantic information .
We explain this distinction and we show how this model may be applied to the interpretation of compounds in real texts , provided that complementary semantic information are retrieved .

Entity-the_automated_interpretation_of_n.label: the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English
aliases: the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English
Entity-the_automated_interpretation_of_n.description: The automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English refers to a domain-independent model designed to systematically analyze and derive meanings from compound nouns based on their morpho-syntactic and semantic properties, utilizing principles of predicative information to distinguish between generalizable and domain-specific semantic interpretations.

mentions.local_name: the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English

Entity-automated_interpretation.label: automated interpretation
Entity-automated_interpretation.description: Automated interpretation refers to a domain-independent model designed to analyze and derive meanings from nominal compounds in English by utilizing morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics.

Entity-the_interpretation_of_compound_in.label: the interpretation of compounds in real texts
aliases: the interpretation of compounds in real texts
Entity-the_interpretation_of_compound_in.description: The interpretation of compounds in real texts refers to the process of applying a domain-independent model to analyze and understand the meaning of nominal compounds in English by utilizing morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics, as well as complementary semantic information.

mentions.local_name: the interpretation of compounds in real texts

Entity-this_distinction.label: this distinction
Entity-this_distinction.description: This distinction refers to the necessary separation between generalizable semantic principles and domain-specific semantic information in the context of interpreting nominal compounds.

Entity-principle.label: principles
Entity-principle.description: The term 'principles' refers to Pustejovsky's theoretical framework that outlines the predicative information associated with nominal compounds in English.

Entity-predicative_information_associate.label: predicative information associated with nominals
Entity-predicative_information_associate.description: Predicative information associated with nominals refers to the semantic and syntactic characteristics that define how nominal constituents can convey meaning in a predicative manner, as outlined by Pustejovsky's principles, particularly in the context of interpreting nominal compounds.

Entity-the_interpretation_of_compound.label: the interpretation of compounds
Entity-the_interpretation_of_compound.description: The interpretation of compounds refers to the process of understanding and analyzing the meaning of nominal compounds in English, utilizing a domain-independent model that incorporates morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of their constituents.

Entity-predicative_information.label: predicative information
aliases: the predicative information associated with nominals
Entity-predicative_information.description: Predicative information refers to the semantic characteristics and roles that nominals can assume in a sentence, as outlined by Pustejovsky's principles, which help in understanding how these elements contribute to meaning in the context of nominal compounds.

mentions.local_name: the predicative information associated with nominals

Entity-generalizable_semantic_principle.label: generalizable semantic principles
Entity-generalizable_semantic_principle.description: Generalizable semantic principles refer to overarching rules or guidelines for interpreting the meanings of nominal compounds that apply across various domains, distinguishing them from specific semantic information tied to particular contexts.

Entity-model.label: model
Entity-model.description: The 'model' refers to a domain-independent computational framework designed for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English, focusing on the morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of the constituents.

Entity-productive_rule_of_interpretation.label: productive rules of interpretation
Entity-productive_rule_of_interpretation.description: Productive rules of interpretation refer to the systematic guidelines derived from the morpho-syntactic and semantic features of nominal constituents that facilitate the automated understanding of nominal compounds in English.

Entity-complementary_semantic_informatio.label: complementary semantic information
Entity-complementary_semantic_informatio.description: Complementary semantic information refers to the additional contextual or domain-specific knowledge that enhances the understanding and interpretation of nominal compounds in English, as utilized in a model for automated interpretation.

Entity-morpho-syntactic_and_semantic_cha.label: morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics
Entity-morpho-syntactic_and_semantic_cha.description: The term 'morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics' refers to the structural and meaning-related features of nominal constituents that are utilized to derive rules for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English.

Entity-semantic_characteristic.label: semantic characteristics
Entity-semantic_characteristic.description: The term 'semantic characteristics' refers to the features related to meaning that are derived from the morpho-syntactic properties of nominal constituents, which are essential for interpreting nominal compounds in English.

Entity-semantic_principle.label: semantic principles
Entity-semantic_principle.description: Semantic principles refer to the generalizable rules and frameworks that govern the interpretation of meaning in language, distinguishing them from specific semantic information tied to particular domains.

Entity-real_text.label: real texts
Entity-real_text.description: Real texts refer to actual written materials or documents in English that can be analyzed for the interpretation of nominal compounds using the proposed domain-independent model.

Entity-nominal.label: nominals
Entity-nominal.description: In this context, 'nominals' refers to linguistic expressions that function as nouns or noun phrases, particularly in the study of their morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics within the framework of automated interpretation of nominal compounds.

Entity-domain_independent_model.label: domain independent model
Entity-domain_independent_model.description: A domain independent model is a theoretical framework designed to function across various domains without being tailored to a specific context or subject area.

Entity-domain-specific_semantic_informat.label: domain-specific semantic information
Entity-domain-specific_semantic_informat.description: Domain-specific semantic information refers to the specialized knowledge and contextual meanings associated with specific domains or fields, which differ from generalizable semantic principles.

Entity-nominal_compound.label: nominal compounds
Entity-nominal_compound.description: Nominal compounds are linguistic constructs formed by combining two or more words to create a single noun that conveys a specific meaning, often representing a relationship between the components.

Entity-nominal_constituent.label: nominal constituents
Entity-nominal_constituent.description: Nominal constituents are linguistic elements that function as phrases or components within a sentence, typically representing entities, objects, or concepts.

Entity-pustejovsky.label: Pustejovsky
Entity-pustejovsky.description: Pustejovsky refers to a theorist and researcher known for contributions in the field of linguistics, particularly in relation to the semantics of language.

Entity-english.label: English
Entity-english.description: English is a West Germanic language that is the primary language spoken in England and widely used as a global lingua franca.

summary: A domain independent model is proposed for the automated interpretation of nominal compounds in English . This model is meant to account for productive rules of interpretation which are inferred from the morpho-syntactic and semantic characteristics of the nominal constituents . In particular , we make extensive use of Pustejovsky 's principles concerning the predicative information associated with nominals . We argue that it is necessary to draw a line between generalizable semantic principles and domain-specific semantic information . We explain this distinction and we show how this model may be applied to the interpretation of compounds in real texts , provided that complementary semantic information are retrieved .

Predicate-is_proposed_for.label: is proposed for
Predicate-is_proposed_for.description: The predicate 'is proposed for' indicates a suggestion or recommendation regarding the intended use or application of the subject. It connects the subject to the object by implying that the subject is being put forward as a potential solution, method, or approach to address the needs or challenges represented by the object.

Predicate-is_meant_to_account_for.label: is meant to account for
Predicate-is_meant_to_account_for.description: The predicate 'is meant to account for' establishes a relationship where the subject is intended to provide an explanation, justification, or framework for understanding the object. It implies that the subject serves a purpose in elucidating or representing the object, suggesting that the object is a key aspect or component that the subject addresses or incorporates.

Predicate-are_inferred_from.label: are inferred from
Predicate-are_inferred_from.description: The predicate 'are inferred from' establishes a relationship where the subject is derived or deduced based on the information or evidence provided by the object. It indicates that the characteristics or properties of the subject can be understood or concluded by analyzing the details or features represented by the object.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' serves to establish a relationship of belonging, association, or specification between the subject and the object in a triple. It indicates that the subject possesses certain qualities, attributes, or characteristics that are relevant to the object, thereby linking the two in a way that clarifies the nature of their connection.

Predicate-concerning.label: concerning
Predicate-concerning.description: The predicate 'concerning' establishes a relationship of relevance or association between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is related to, or has a focus on, the information or concept represented by the object. It suggests that the subject is in some way addressing, dealing with, or pertaining to the object, thereby providing context or a framework for understanding the subject in relation to the object.

Predicate-draw_a_line_between.label: draw a line between
Predicate-draw_a_line_between.description: The predicate 'draw a line between' signifies the act of establishing a distinction or differentiation between two concepts, entities, or categories. It implies a comparative analysis that highlights the boundaries or contrasts that separate the subject from the object, often to clarify their respective roles, characteristics, or relevance in a given context.

Predicate-applied_to.label: applied to
Predicate-applied_to.description: The predicate 'applied to' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the object, suggesting that the subject serves a functional role or purpose in addressing, analyzing, or engaging with the object in a specific context.

Predicate-retrieved.label: retrieved
Predicate-retrieved.description: The predicate 'retrieved' indicates an action or process in which the subject is involved in obtaining or accessing specific information or data represented by the object. It implies a transfer of knowledge or insight from a source to the subject, highlighting the subject's role in acquiring or extracting relevant content from a broader context.

Predicate-may_be_applied_to.label: may be applied to
Predicate-may_be_applied_to.description: The predicate 'may be applied to' indicates a potential or permissible relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject can be utilized or implemented in relation to the object. This implies that the subject has relevance or utility in the context of the object, allowing for the possibility of interaction, influence, or application in a specific domain or scenario.

Predicate-are_retrieved_for.label: are retrieved for
Predicate-are_retrieved_for.description: The predicate 'are retrieved for' indicates a relationship where the subject is obtained or accessed in order to fulfill a specific purpose or need represented by the object. It suggests that the subject serves as a source or resource that provides necessary information, support, or context relevant to the object.

Predicate-is_a_specific_application_of.label: is a specific application of
Predicate-is_a_specific_application_of.description: The predicate 'is a specific application of' establishes a relationship where the subject represents a particular instance or implementation that utilizes the broader concept or methodology indicated by the object. It signifies that the subject is a concrete example or manifestation of the theoretical or general principles encapsulated in the object.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset of a more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider range of concepts or entities than the subject, thereby situating the subject within a broader conceptual framework.
